did.unittitle: Center for Documentary Studies student projects collection, 1980-2011 and undated

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies.

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University teaches, engages in, and presents documentary work grounded in collaborative partnerships and extended fieldwork that uses photography, film/video, audio, and narrative writing to capture and convey contemporary memory, life, and culture. The collection houses work created by students enrolled in documentary studies courses at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), sponsored by the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke. The student projects focus primarily on exploring and documenting the social lives and experiences of people living in and around rural and urban areas of Durham, Chatham, and Orange counties, North Carolina, through photography or oral history. Subjects include but are not limited to local school environments; churches and religious life; ethnic communities and neighborhoods; war veterans; the 9/11 attacks; the labor and civil rights movements as experienced by local individuals; students at Duke University; farmers and their families; immigrant life; migrant workers; beauty pageants; local music scenes; and the built environment and culture of North Carolina towns, and cities. Audiovisual materials include sound recordings and moving images, and may require reformatting before contents can be accessed. Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Portions of the collection are restricted.
Original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.p: Images are for research use only and may not be reproduced or distributed in any way without written permission of creator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Center for Documentary Studies student projects, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Levi Crews, Marlyse Hickman-MacDonald, Edward Holt, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Maria Perales, T. Walker Robinson, and Matthew Warren, 1997-2014
Encoded by Levi Crews, Marlyse Hickman-MacDonald, Edward Holt, Robin LaPasha, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Maria Perales, and Matthew Warren, 1997-2014

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection houses photographs, interviews, essays, and other documentary works created by students enrolled in courses or thesis projects on documentary studies at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), from 1980 to 2011. Most of the student projects focus on the social life and customs of persons living in and around Durham, Chatham, and Orange counties, North Carolina. Themes include life in cities and towns, particularly in Durham; rural life; schools and other institutions such as churches and retirement homes, and charitable organizations such as soup kitchens and orphanages; community centers such as stores, daycares, and laundromats; African American communities and neighborhoods, particularly in Durham; beauty pageants; local music; farmers and their families; immigrant life; migrant workers; midwives; the 9/11 attacks in New York City; and Duke University students and campus life. One series of images portrays the Chuck Davis African American Dance Ensemble in Durham. Oral histories of N.C. civil rights and labor activists, American war veterans, and other individuals are associated with certain courses.

The majority of projects focus on Durham area locales, but other cities and towns in N.C. documented include Chapel Hill, Hillsborough, Raleigh, Seagrove, Wanchese, Cane Creek, Oxford, Carrboro, Orange Factory, Rougemont, Saxapahaw, Salisbury, Northside, Corinth, and Cedar Grove. There are a few projects based in Virginia, and summer projects located in Massachusetts, Tennessee, Tel-Aviv, and France.

The collection also includes a few grant-supported projects by professional documentarians Eric Green, Kate Rhodenbaugh, Carolina Wang, and Donna Lennard, and photographic work by Bill Bamberger, a faculty member at Duke.

Black-and-white prints make up the majority of formats, but there are also many slides. The more recent additions increasingly include oral histories on audio cassettes and CD-ROMS and other project-related digital media. These are marked in the folder descriptions. Original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use and may require the production of use copies before they can be accessed.

The courses were all sponsored by the Center for Documentary Photography, which in 1989 changed its name to the Center for Documentary Studies. Among the faculty teaching courses for the Center for Documentary Studies are noted documentarians Bill Bamberger, John Biewen, David Cecelski, Alex Harris, and Margaret Sartor, some of whom have contributed their own documentary work to the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.p: Project folders are arranged chronologically by year, then by course number and title; within course groupings, student projects are listed in alphabetical order by last name. Some earlier listings do not have an identified course title. Individual projects such as senior year work (sometimes called a "capstone" project) have separate entries within the appropriate year. Titles and captions were created by the documentary authors; bracketed titles have been supplied by library staff.

did.unittitle: Duke, HIST 195S, The Coastal South, Fall 2001

scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course consist of interviews with individuals who live or have lived along the southern coast, specifically the coastal Carolinas. Folders typically contain the student's essays, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects, and photographs or other media.

userestrict.p: Oral history recordings are open to research use. However, any other use, distribution, or publication is subject to privacy laws, and permission must be obtained from interviewee.

accessrestrict.p: [Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.]

Venturing to Deltaville, Virginia Through the Lens of a Camera

scopecontent.p: Contains black-and-white photographs of Bullock's BBQ, a restaurant in Durham, N.C. established in 1952 that specializes in "Southern cooking and catering." Prints are not captioned.
"Kinetic Kultur" and "Dale Earhardt Memorial." Durham, Fairmont and Fayetteville, N.C.
"The Last Parade." "Cemetery Photography." "Sept. 11, 2001." Chapel Hill, Hillsborough and Carrboro, N.C.
"Multi-racial and Gay Parent Family." Three black-and-white prints.
"Behind the Scenes: Aurora." Chapel Hill, N.C. Slide format only.

did.unittitle: Duke, HIST 106S, Wars on the Homefront (1940-2001), Spring 2002

scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course taught by David Cecelski consist of interviews with individuals who lived through wars from 1940-2001, specifically World War II, Vietnam, and the attack on the World Trade Center. Folders typically contain the student's essays, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects, and sometimes CD-roms or other media.

userestrict.p: Oral history recordings are open to research use. However, any other use, distribution, or publication is subject to privacy laws, and permission must be obtained from interviewee.

accessrestrict.p: [Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.]

scopecontent.p: U-Boats Off Our Coast. One CD-Rom enclosed.
Stories of World War II and Vietnam Veterans One CD-Rom enclosed.
A Human Tragedy Not a National Tragedy [1 spiral scrapbook enclosed.

p.title: In Search of the Cold War: An American Era All Too Easily Forgotten
The Center of a Vet: Encounters at the Raleigh Vet Center
Portraits of World War II Veterans
World War II: A Female Perspective

scopecontent.p: Rye Country Day School, Thoughts on 9/11. One VHS tape enclosed.

p.title: The Reaction of American Muslims to the September 11th Attacks: A Collection of Six Short Interviews

scopecontent.p: A Whole New World Experience: An Interview with Mr. Felix Subervi, World War II Veteran. Three CD-roms enclosed.
Interview of William Herrara Beardal. Spiral scrapbook contains transcript of interview, plus a timeline of the Vietnam Conflict.
A Soldier and a Hero: The Changing Face of the American Veteran. Essay with extracts from oral history interviews with half a dozen veterans of different wars.

From the Mother County to the Empirial [sic] City. Oral history interview with an African American woman, Alma Atkinson Jones, from Elizabethtown, Bladen County. Spiral scrapbook contains maps, color snapshots, photocopies of historical images, captions, and quotations from the interview transcript, also housed in the project folder.

Raymond Lee Eurquhart--War Resister. Essay and oral history interview with Raymond Lee Eurquhart concerning the Vietnam Conflict. Also includes photocopies of archival documents (letters and clippings).
Little Buoys in Pearl Harbor. Essay and oral history interview with Carroll Robbins Jones on her childhood experience in World War II.

The Shadow of the World Trade Center. Essay and extracts of interviews with witnesses to the September 11, 2001 attack on the World Trade Center in New York City. Includes images of the interviewees and scenes from that day embedded in the text .
"Mrs. Das's Kindergarten Class." Durham, N.C. Slides in addition to prints.
"3 year old classroom- Duke School for Children." Durham, N.C. Slide format only.
"Final Project." One-page essay on her project, which mixes popular music pieces with commentary about the 9/11 attacks and military service. One CD-rom enclosed.

Spiral notebook with mini-disk included. Journal contains entries reflecting on the process of finding interviewees and developing a focused topic and a set of questions. Topic chosen seems to have to do with World War II and women's roles.
"The 'White Girls'." Essay in which "three sisters tell about their WWII home front experience in Locker, Texas."
Images on color slides seems to come from a school and a kitchen. There is no other information with this untitled project.
Black-and-white contact prints of construction workers on housing project. Prints measure 8x10 inches.
"Love and Strength." Durham, N.C. Slide format only.

did.unittitle: DOCST 177S: Advanced Documentary Photography, Tom Rankin

scopecontent.p: Release forms for this class are in box 65. The projects are physically housed in a number of differently-sized boxes for best housing.
Four black-and-white prints depicting storefront churches, at least one of which is in Durham, N.C. Two of the prints are mounted on board.
Five uncut square black-and-white contact prints depicting railroad locations in Durham, N.C. such as sidings and tracks.
"Final Project." The square black-and-white contact prints measure between 6 to 7 inches and are mounted on 11x14 inch white boards; they also depict rail transportation locations in Durham, N.C.

did.unittitle: Duke, DOCST 198, Documenting the Civil Rights Movement in North Carolina, Fall 2003

scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course consist of interviews with individuals who were directly involved in the Civil Rights Movement in North Carolina. Folders typically contain CD-Roms or other media, and the student's project statements, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects.

userestrict.p: Oral history recordings are open to research use. However, any other use, distribution, or publication is subject to privacy laws, and permission must be obtained from interviewee.

accessrestrict.p: [Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.]

did.unittitle: Duke, DOCST 117, Documenting Southern Culture, Spring 2004

scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course consist of photographs capturing various communities within and traits of the American South. Folders contain black-and-white photographs measuring 5x7 and 8x10 inches, and the student's project statements, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects.

did.unittitle: Bluegrass: The Culture of Music color photographic prints, 2010

scopecontent.p: Student projects for this University of North Carolina, CDS-sponsored course consist of oral history interviews with individuals who live or have lived along the Southern coast, specifically the coastal Carolinas. Project folders typically contain interviews on CD-ROMs or other media, along with student essays which explore the process of choosing a theme and the unfolding of the documentary work.

userestrict.p: Oral history recordings are open to research use. However, any other use, distribution, or publication is subject to privacy laws, and permission must be obtained from interviewee.

accessrestrict.p: [Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.]

did.unittitle: Independent Study: Portrait of TROSA, Silver, Jessica

scopecontent.p: Contains photographic color portraits of male and female residents of Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers (TROSA). The prints are signed and captioned by the portrait sitter. Captions are meant to answer the question "What does this photograph say about you?" Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.]

did.unittitle: Portrait of TROSA color photographic prints, 2008
Southern Culture Through Photography: Timberwood Organics, Rappaport, Alex

scopecontent.p: Project consists of color photographs taken at Timberwood Organics, an organic farm in Efland, North Carolina that is owned by Ray Christopher. Digital inkjet prints measure 13x19 inches and are not captioned. Also contains a CD-Rom with the image files.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.]

did.unittitle: Capstone Project, Certificate of Documentary Studies: Illumination, Jennifer Kozin

scopecontent.p: Senior project by Kozin comprises nocturnal color portraits of Duke University students taken in various locations in and around the Duke campus, including campus classrooms, the Nasher Art Museum, Perkins Library, athletic fields, apartments, campus parking lots, bus stops, and a few nightspots in Durham and Hillsborough, North Carolina. The set starts off with two prints containing the project title and introductory text: "The following scenes were captured between the hours of 10 PM and 4 AM at and around Duke University from October 2009 to March 2010." Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when handling these prints.]

scopecontent.p: Contains iconic-remakes of well-known works of art, featuring Duke University students posing as Rosie the Riveter, John Lennon and Yoko Ono, the Girl With the Pearl Earring, Magritte's Son of Adam, Marines raising the flag at Iwo Jima, the Beatles crossing Abbey Road, and others. Prints are not captioned. includes print-outs of original iconic images with text by Jeffery. Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.]

did.unittitle: Duke DOCST 135S, Intro to Audio Documentary

scopecontent.p: Contains one CD-Rom on which each student's final audio project is accessible. The class was taught by Professor John Biewen.

did.unittitle: Senior Thesis: Beauty Pageants in the South, Nettles, Kim, 2011

scopecontent.p: This collection was formed to complement Nettles's thesis, Victimization and the Ethics of Photography. Contains photographs taken chiefly at children's beauty pageants in North Carolina. Prints are titled and captioned on accompanying title sheet. Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.]

did.unittitle: Beauty Pageants in the South, color prints, 2011
DOCST 117: Documentary Photography and the Southern Cultural Landscape, 2011

scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course consist of photographs that attempt to capture elements and themes of Southern culture. Photographs are typically accompanied by the student's essays, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects. Unless otherwise noted, all prints are black-and-white and measure 8.5x11 inches.
Bluegrass in North Carolina. Digital color prints.
Structure Poetry in Southern Cities Digital color prints.
Durham County Wildlife Club Digital color prints.

[Untitled] Digital inkjet color photographs explore abandoned homesites surrounding the author's hometown of Rolesville, N.C.; the images then turn to portraits of the author's Haitian-born family, playing dominoes and bezique and eating traditional Haitian foods in their Rolesville home. Prints measure 13x19 inches.
These projects are missing information such as dates and project titles, or course title. They currently do not have release forms.

"Documenting the Ronald McDonald House." Single black-and-white print of a boy with a Ronald McDonald sweatshirt and a hat, mounted in an 11.5x14 inch window mat that is glued to foamcore board. The image measures 9 3/4 x 6 5/8 inches. May be the missing print in the album listed below. Student essay is included in folder.

"Documenting the Ronald McDonald House." One black album with 14 black-and-white prints mounted with photo corners, documenting a guest house in Durham, N.C. for families who have children at Duke Hospital. Album missing one print: probably single print listed above.
"Documenting Southern Culture." Essay included. Images were taken in Durham, N.C., chiefly close-ups. Includes areas around 9th Street. Digital color prints measure 8.5x11 inches.
Untitled. Four black-and-white images taken at a convenience store/gas station. Prints measure 9 7/8 x 7 7/8 inches.

Eight photography projects created by unidentified students for documentary classes. Topics include religion, kitchens and markets, a goat herd, and abandoned schools. Includes color as well as black-and-white prints; the color are all digitally printed. No release forms.

userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.

scopecontent.p: Black-and-white images of old-time stringband, with several shots of dancers. Prints measure 8x10 inches.
Matted black-and-white images of a diner's kitchen. Prints measure 5 x 7 3/4 inches and 8x10 inches.
Digital inkjet color images of seafood markets. Prints measure 13x19 inches.
Digital inkjet color images of an abandoned school building's classrooms and grounds. Prints measure 13x19 inches.
Digital inkjet color images of the interiors, products, and personnel in two ethnic grocery stores - one Asian and one Hispanic. Prints measure 14x16 inches.

Each color image is accompanied by first-person captions handwritten by the individuals portrayed in the photographs, consisting of self-reflections on their religious customs and practices. Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches, mounted on black boards measuring 16x20 inches.
Black-and-white photographs of goats in a milking parlor, unknown location. Prints measure 11x14 inches.
Matted black-and-white prints of a Hispanic men's community soccer league in a game. Prints measure approximately 6x9 inches.
